title: `EnvFiles` feature (KEP-3721): Unclear quote handling behavior

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

labels.name: sig/node
labels.description: Categorizes an issue or PR as relevant to SIG Node.

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: Indicates an issue or PR lacks a `triage/foo` label and requires one.

body:
### What happened?

I'm interested in and testing the EnvFiles feature ([KEP-3721](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/blob/master/keps/sig-node/3721-support-for-env-files/README.md)) and found that quote handling behavior is unclear and inconsistent with how ConfigMap handles quotes.

I may be misunderstanding something,
but I expected consistent quote handling behavior, similar to how ConfigMap works.

**Current behavior with EnvFiles:**

When using FileKeyRef with an env file containing:
```bash
SIMPLE=value
API_TOKEN='abc123'
DB_HOST="localhost"
JSON_DATA='{"key": "value"}'
```

The resulting environment variables include the quotes as literal characters:
```bash
SIMPLE=value                 # No quotes
API_TOKEN='abc123'           # Quotes preserved
DB_HOST="localhost"          # Quotes preserved  
JSON_DATA='{"key": "value"}' # Quotes preserved
```

**Comparison with ConfigMap:**

For reference, ConfigMap strips YAML quotes:
```yaml
data:
  API_TOKEN: "'abc123'"
  DB_HOST: "localhost"
  JSON_DATA: '{"key": "value"}'
  SIMPLE=value
```

Results in:
```bash
API_TOKEN='abc123'           # YAML outer quotes removed
DB_HOST=localhost            # YAML quotes removed
JSON_DATA={"key": "value"}   # YAML quotes removed
SIMPLE=value
```

**Documentation inconsistencies:**

1. KEP states: "[Values must be enclosed in single quotes (e.g., VAR='value').](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/blob/master/keps/sig-node/3721-support-for-env-files/README.md#env-file)".
2. KEP also states: "[Any env file supported by k8s will yield the same environment variables as if it was interpreted by bash.](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/blob/master/keps/sig-node/3721-support-for-env-files/README.md#env-file)"
3. [Official blog post](https://kubernetes.io/blog/2025/09/10/kubernetes-v1-34-env-files/#how-it-works) shows examples **without** quotes: `echo "CONFIG_VAR=HELLO" > /config/config.env`
4. Test cases only cover values `without` quotes

### What did you expect to happen?

I expected consistent quote handling behavior, similar to how ConfigMap works.
I want to know this difference is intentional or not.

ConfigMap strips quotes, but EnvFiles preserves them. For example:
```yaml
# ConfigMap
data:
  TOKEN: 'abc123'
# Result: TOKEN=abc123 (quotes removed)
```
```bash
# EnvFiles
TOKEN='abc123'
# Result: TOKEN='abc123' (quotes preserved)
```

### How can we reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)?

1. Create a test pod with EnvFiles:

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  name: envfiles-test
spec:
  initContainers:
  - name: setup
    image: busybox
    command: 
      - sh
      - -c
      - |
        cat > /data/config.env << 'EOF'
        API_TOKEN='abc123'
        DB_HOST="localhost"
        SIMPLE=value
        JSON='{"key": "value"}'
        EOF
    volumeMounts:
    - name: config
      mountPath: /data
  containers:
  - name: test
    image: busybox
    command: ["sh", "-c", "sleep 3600"]
    env:
    - name: API_TOKEN
      valueFrom:
        fileKeyRef:
          path: config.env
          volumeName: config
          key: API_TOKEN
    - name: DB_HOST
      valueFrom:
        fileKeyRef:
          path: config.env
          volumeName: config
          key: DB_HOST
    - name: SIMPLE
      valueFrom:
        fileKeyRef:
          path: config.env
          volumeName: config
          key: SIMPLE
    - name: JSON
      valueFrom:
        fileKeyRef:
          path: config.env
          volumeName: config
          key: JSON
  volumes:
  - name: config
    emptyDir: {}
```

2. Check environment variables:
```bash
kubectl exec envfiles-test -- sh -c 'printf "API_TOKEN=[%s]\n" "$API_TOKEN"'
kubectl exec envfiles-test -- sh -c 'printf "DB_HOST=[%s]\n" "$DB_HOST"'
kubectl exec envfiles-test -- sh -c 'printf "SIMPLE=[%s]\n" "$SIMPLE"'
kubectl exec envfiles-test -- sh -c 'printf "JSON=[%s]\n" "$JSON"'
```

3. Observe that quotes are preserved in the values
```bash
API_TOKEN=['abc123']
DB_HOST=["localhost"]
SIMPLE=[value]
JSON=['{"key": "value"}']
```

### Anything else we need to know?

_No response_

### Kubernetes version

<details>

```console
$ kubectl version
v1.34.0 (with EnvFiles feature gate enabled)
```

</details>


### Cloud provider

<details>
kind
</details>


### OS version

<details>

```console
# On Linux:
$ cat /etc/os-release
# paste output here
$ uname -a
# paste output here

# On Windows:
C:\> wmic os get Caption, Version, BuildNumber, OSArchitecture
# paste output here
```

</details>


### Install tools

<details>

</details>


### Container runtime (CRI) and version (if applicable)

<details>

</details>


### Related plugins (CNI, CSI, ...) and versions (if applicable)

<details>

</details>

title: Limitation of more than 64 backend pods for a Single Service on Windows nodes needs to be removed from documentation

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

labels.name: needs-sig
labels.description: Indicates an issue or PR lacks a `sig/foo` label and requires one.

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: Indicates an issue or PR lacks a `triage/foo` label and requires one.

body:
### What happened?

https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/windows-networking/#limitations states the following as one of the things _not_ supported:
> More than 64 backend pods (or unique destination addresses) for a single Service

The original trigger for this documentation is https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/98680 apparently, which led to https://github.com/microsoft/Windows-Containers/issues/93. Comments in the latter issue say that the issue has been fixed with the limit increased to 1024. By now (3 years later), I believe the limitation has been fixed in Windows Server in both 2019 and 2022.

### What did you expect to happen?

If the above is true, then can the limitation be removed from the documentation?

### How can we reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)?

Documentation needs update, no repro required.

### Anything else we need to know?

FWIW, in my test with an Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) cluster and a Windows Server 2022 node pool, I created a StatefulSet with 70 Windows pods behind a ClusterIP Service - didn't observe any issue on any of the Windows nodes.

### Kubernetes version

<details>

```console
$ kubectl version
Client Version: v1.29.7
Kustomize Version: v5.0.4-0.20230601165947-6ce0bf390ce3
Server Version: v1.33.3
```

</details>


### Cloud provider

<details>
Azure
</details>


### OS version

<details>

```console
# On Linux:
$ cat /etc/os-release
PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS"
NAME="Ubuntu"
VERSION_ID="22.04"
VERSION="22.04.5 LTS (Jammy Jellyfish)"
VERSION_CODENAME=jammy
ID=ubuntu
ID_LIKE=debian
HOME_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://help.ubuntu.com/"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/"
PRIVACY_POLICY_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/legal/terms-and-policies/privacy-policy"
UBUNTU_CODENAME=jammy
$ uname -a
Linux aks-default-58694455-vmss00000P 5.15.0-1098-azure #107-Ubuntu SMP Thu Oct 2 22:41:20 UTC 2025 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

# On Windows:
C:\> wmic os get Caption, Version, BuildNumber, OSArchitecture
BuildNumber  Caption                                   OSArchitecture  Version
20348        Microsoft Windows Server 2022 Datacenter  64-bit          10.0.20348
```

</details>


### Install tools

<details>

</details>


### Container runtime (CRI) and version (if applicable)

<details>

</details>


### Related plugins (CNI, CSI, ...) and versions (if applicable)

<details>

</details>

title: PV Controller: add configurable concurrent syncs for PersistentVolume controller

labels.name: release-note
labels.description: Denotes a PR that will be considered when it comes time to generate release notes.

labels.name: size/M
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 30-99 lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: kind/api-change
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to adding, removing, or otherwise changing an API

labels.name: kind/feature
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a new feature.

labels.name: sig/apps
labels.description: Categorizes an issue or PR as relevant to SIG Apps.

labels.name: cncf-cla: yes
labels.description: Indicates the PR's author has signed the CNCF CLA.

labels.name: ok-to-test
labels.description: Indicates a non-member PR verified by an org member that is safe to test.

labels.name: needs-priority
labels.description: Indicates a PR lacks a `priority/foo` label and requires one.

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: Indicates an issue or PR lacks a `triage/foo` label and requires one.

body:
<!--  Thanks for sending a pull request!  Here are some tips for you:

1. If this is your first time, please read our contributor guidelines: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/guide/first-contribution.md#your-first-contribution and developer guide https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/development.md#development-guide
2. Please label this pull request according to what type of issue you are addressing, especially if this is a release targeted pull request. For reference on required PR/issue labels, read here:
https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-release/release.md#issuepr-kind-label
3. Ensure you have added or ran the appropriate tests for your PR: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-testing/testing.md
4. If you want *faster* PR reviews, read how: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/guide/pull-requests.md#best-practices-for-faster-reviews
5. If the PR is unfinished, see how to mark it: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/guide/pull-requests.md#marking-unfinished-pull-requests
-->

#### What type of PR is this?

<!--
Add one of the following kinds:
/kind bug
/kind cleanup
/kind documentation
/kind feature

Optionally add one or more of the following kinds if applicable:
/kind api-change
/kind deprecation
/kind failing-test
/kind flake
/kind regression
-->

/kind feature

#### What this PR does / why we need it:

Previously, the PV controller ran with a fixed number of workers (one volume worker and one claim worker). This change makes the worker count configurable so that operators can increase concurrency, improving controller responsiveness and reducing PVC binding latency introduced by the periodic (15s by default) resync of the volume and claim workqueues.

#### Which issue(s) this PR is related to:
<!--
Please link relevant issues to help with tracking.

To automatically close the linked issue(s) when this PR is merged,
add the word "Fixes" before the issue number or link.
Do not use "Fixes" if the PR is of kind `failing-test` or `flake`.

Reference KEPs when applicable in addition to specific issues.

Examples:
Fixes #<issue number>
<issue link> (issue in a different repository)
KEP: https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/issues/<kep-issue-number>

If there is no associated issue, then write "N/A".
-->

#### Special notes for your reviewer:

#### Does this PR introduce a user-facing change?
<!--
If no, just write "NONE" in the release-note block below.
If yes, a release note is required:
Enter your extended release note in the block below. If the PR requires additional action from users switching to the new release, include the string "action required".

For more information on release notes see: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/guide/release-notes.md
-->
```release-note
Add --pvclaimbinder-concurrent-syncs flag to configure PV controller workers.
```

#### Additional documentation e.g., KEPs (Kubernetes Enhancement Proposals), usage docs, etc.:

<!--
This section can be blank if this pull request does not require a release note.

When adding links which point to resources within git repositories, like
KEPs or supporting documentation, please reference a specific commit and avoid
linking directly to the master branch. This ensures that links reference a
specific point in time, rather than a document that may change over time.

See here for guidance on getting permanent links to files: https://help.github.com/en/articles/getting-permanent-links-to-files

Please use the following format for linking documentation:
- [KEP]: <link>
- [Usage]: <link>
- [Other doc]: <link>
-->
```docs

```

body:

/kind feature

**What this PR does / why we need it:**

Enables validation-gen for `scheduling.k8s.io v1/v1alpha1/v1beta1` API group

â€¢ Adds DV support for PriorityClass

**Which issue(s) this PR is related to:**

part of #134280

**Special notes for your reviewer:**

This PR does NOT migrate any validations: validation rules migration would be introduced in separate PRs.

**Does this PR introduce a user-facing change?**

```release-note
NONE
```
**Additional documentation, e.g., KEPs (Kubernetes Enhancement Proposals), usage docs, etc.:**

title: Add explicit type to feature gate const declarations

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

labels.name: priority/important-soon
labels.description: Must be staffed and worked on either currently, or very soon, ideally in time for the next release.

labels.name: kind/cleanup
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to cleaning up code, process, or technical debt.

labels.name: lgtm
labels.description: "Looks good to me", indicates that a PR is ready to be merged.

labels.name: size/XS
labels.description: Denotes a PR that changes 0-9 lines, ignoring generated files.

labels.name: release-note-none
labels.description: Denotes a PR that doesn't merit a release note.

labels.name: approved
labels.description: Indicates a PR has been approved by an approver from all required OWNERS files.

labels.name: cncf-cla: yes
labels.description: Indicates the PR's author has signed the CNCF CLA.

labels.name: sig/architecture
labels.description: Categorizes an issue or PR as relevant to SIG Architecture.

labels.name: do-not-merge/hold
labels.description: Indicates that a PR should not merge because someone has issued a /hold command.

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: Indicates an issue or PR lacks a `triage/foo` label and requires one.

body:
Two feature gate constants were missing the explicit `featuregate.Feature` type annotation, making them inconsistent with the rest of the file:
- ChangeContainerStatusOnKubeletRestart
- StatefulSetSemanticRevisionComparison

This will also ensure that these feature flags will get listed in `--help` output
